channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2024010239
item.description:
Report E-2024010239

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-09
  • City: TROY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 9, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon box of UN1824 fell in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to remediate the impacted site. MEG personnel deployed granular absorbents, neutralizer and absorbent pads to the sodium hydroxide solution-impacted trailer interior and impacted pallets. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010229
item.description:
Report E-2024010229

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-05
  • City: EL PASO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: GrayMar Environmental Services was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft- by-2ft area of the concrete trailer yard and a 10ft-by-15ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that twenty (20) gallons of material was released due to a nail puncture from a pallet during offloading that damaged one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. GrayMar Environmental Services personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and recovered the spent material and containerized into one (1) 55- gallon metal drum. The damaged metal drum was over-packed into one (1) 65-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was stage onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010241
item.description:
Report E-2024010241

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-10
  • City: ELLENWOOD
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 10, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3098 was damaged during shipping and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel collected one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail of UN3098 and containerized it in one (1) 55-gallon drum. Crews then deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and worked them in using hand tools. FCE personnel utilized absorbent wipes to remediate any residual product. All UN3098 impacted material was collected and containerized in three (3) 55-gallon drums for disposal by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2024010281
item.description:
Report E-2024010281

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-10
  • City: HUNTSVILLE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 10, 2024, two (2) 275-gallon totes of UN1866 were crushed in transit and released approximately 300-gallons of product to the trailer interior and adjacent freight. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel unloaded the trailer, wiping freight as it was being transferred out of the trailer. Crews then deployed absorbents to the paint thinner impacted trailer interior. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into 55-gallon drums for terminal disposal. HES transferred the remaining contents from the two (2) 275-gallon totes to one (1) new 275-gallon and two (2) 55-gallons drums. The damaged totes were cut into pieces and placed into two(55-gallon drums. HES removed seven (7) pallets that were damaged and/or impacted by the paint thinner. Additional damaged/impacted freight including aerosol cans of break cleaner and freon were removed and placed into 55-gallon drums for disposal. A total of 15 55-gallon drums of waste were generated and staged onsite for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010274
item.description:
Report E-2024010274

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-10
  • City: ELDRIDGE
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 10, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3082 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel observed that R+L had placed granular absorbents to all impacted areas. ES began sweeping all absorbents up with hand tools and placed the one (1) leaking 55-gallon drum into one 85-gallon drum . All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum to be staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: On January 11, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN2055 had a loose valve during transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Mid-South Environmental Services (MSES) to remediate the impacted site. MSES personnel arrived and assessed the site. MSES secured the valve on the tote and a transfer was not needed. Waste accumulated was placed with waste from another job being worked by them in the same area. Crews secured the scene and demobilized.

  • Description: On January 5, 2024, two (2) 5-gallon liter plastic jugs of UN3149 leaked due to improper loading and released approximately one (1) liter of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel collected and containerized all impacted cardboard and debris into one (1) vented 55-gallon poly drum. The two (2) damaged 5-liter jugs were placed into one (1) other vented 55-gallon poly drum. Both drums were labeled as hazardous and staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Description: On January 5, 2024, two (2) 55-gallon drums containing UN1206 were punctured by a forklift and released approximately twenty-five (25) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from SET Environmental (SET) to remediate the impacted site. SET personnel placed each damaged 55-gallon drum into two (2) 85-gallon salvage drums. R+L terminal personnel had contained the release with granular absorbents, so crews swept them in with hand tools. SET personnel utilized simple green and absorbent pads to wipe down the impacted trailer. All spent absorbents and any cleanup debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XGR experienced a UN2491 Bonderite L-GP 505 Corrosion Inhibitor release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to an 8' x 10' area of the trailer floor and a 10' x 25' area of the asphalt dock as well as a catch basin. The release was due to a forklift puncture to the bottom of the drum. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were deployed to clean the impacted trailer floor and collected into (3) 55-gallon poly drums. A pressure washer and vac unit along with citric acid solution were then utilized to clean the impacted asphalt and catch basin. All impacted wastewater was placed into (7) 250-gallon poly totes. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews downstacked the pallet, removed one (1) leaking 5-gallon pail of UN3266 corrosive liquid from the load, and placed it into one (1) 35-gallon poly drum. TLE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the corrosive liquid-impacted trailer and swept them up with hand tools. Crews then wiped down the impacted surfaces and freight with a neutralizing solution and absorbent pads. All spent absorbents and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into the one (1) 35-gallon drum, and both 35-gallon drums generated during this cleanup were staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Description: FRA HM Inspector Steven Myers found HM tank car PROX 47160 placarded class3, UN 3295, loaded with UN3295 Hydrocarbons, Liquid, N.O.S. class 3, PG 1, (natural gasoline) to be venting at the vacuum relief device.   • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UDV experienced a UN2929 Sulfix 9272 Scavenger release from (2) 330-gallon poly totes. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 70-gallons of product released to a 10’ x 10’ area of the trailer floor and a 20’ x 20’ area of the asphalt lot below. The totes were punctured by metal sticking out from the trailer wall. Each tote was transferred into two new totes for shipment on. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The impacted absorbents were then collected into (2) 55-gallon poly, (3) 55-gallon metal, and (3) 95-gallon poly drums. The two damaged totes were then cut up and containerized into (1) 95-gallon poly and (1) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-05
  • City: GEISMAR
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 5, 2023 at 1200 hrs., FRA Hazmat Inspector discovered what appeared to be product running down the sides of PNWX 703091 (Load / UN 3082 / Class 9 / PG III) at CN Geismar Yard. The liquid on the exterior of the railcar was observed coming from the manway. The inspector climbed the railcar and attempted to turn the manway cover bolts by hand but was unsuccessful. The FRA Inspector notified the Dangerous Goods Officer. The Dangerous Goods Officer made all notifications. CN Response Contractor responded and upon approaching the railcar observed moisture on the exterior of the railcar coming from the manway area. Upon further investigation, the manway gasket was found to be pinched which did not provide proper securement of the manway closure. The manway gasket was properly installed, and manway was secured. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated and returned to Transportation.

DescribePack: THE PACKAGE FAILURE WAS IN THE CLOSURE. ONE OF THE GALLONS LEAKED OUT THE PRODUCT INSIDE.   • Description: SequenceEvent: Driver states to BC that PH had HazMat staged on the floor and he moved to a shelf. He believes he hit a bump and it caused the package to burst on the shelf and leak in the van onto other packages. DescribePack: 1.5 gallons of Zep cleaner leaked from bottom of the Gallon bottles in fiberboard box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Driver was instructed to pull over and open the doors of the vehicle. He called the Emergency Response number on the HazMat paperwork but was not assisted. BC met driver and they were able to transfer damaged packages in the back of a straight truck. All cleanup materials were put in a bag and given to PDM upon return. After cleanup, driver did not feel at risk and continued on with his day. Upon return to the station, PDM - Kayla Hoback - equipped PPE (mask, gloves, apron, etc.) and put all damaged packages onto a damage pallet to thoroughly inspect each one. Only 4 packages truly damaged and the remaining were repacked and sent out to customers.

  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 4ft-by-4ft area of the concrete terminal floor and estimated that two (2) gallons of material was released due to a puncture during improper unloading to one (1) 330-gallon metal tote. Hepaco personnel applied a patch kit to the damaged weld seam on the metal tote and containerized the impacted carboard that was used by terminal personnel as absorbents into one 55-gallon metal drum along with absorbent pads and PPE used by Hepaco personnel. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization and will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The trailer was fine until it arrived to offload. Once they started offloading the trailer began dripping 2 drips every 5 seconds. They were able to contain the leak to a bucket and finished the offload so it could be sent for repairs. We're a bit surprised it started leaking at the time it did. Usually when doing a pump offload it creates a 'vacuum' away from the source of the leak and slows it down. In this case this is when it started leaking. I likely has to do with when the internal valve was opened though that allowed it to get to the sump gasket. That is what actually leaked.

item.title: Report X-2024010286
item.description:
Report X-2024010286

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-16T18:13:17+00:00

  • City: ROGERS
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2024010286 SequenceEvent: HAP specialist was going through the unload bank when he spotted the damaged hazmat sitting on the rollers on its side. the package was leaking a slow dribble onto the floor. He called the HESS specialist to ask for a lined tote and cleanup material to perform immediate in-house cleanup. upon completion, HESS specialist brought the package in a lined tote back to the damage area and moved it to the drain mats in the incoming damaged hazmat/LQ area. DescribePack: one bottle leaked due to loose cap. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: immediate in-house cleanup. placed in lined tote, moved to drain mats. 2. X-2024010289 SequenceEvent: HAP specialist discovered this damaged hazmat at the same time as the package in Hazmat Incident No.117328, in the unload. He called HESS specialist to bring him a lined tote and cleanup material. HESS specialist did as requested, then took from him the damaged hazmat in its tote and brought this back to the damage area, placing it atop the drain mats in the incoming damaged hazmat/LQ area. DescribePack: two bottles leaked due to loose caps DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: immediate in-house cleanup performed. placed in lined tote, moved to drain mats. 3. X-2024010300 SequenceEvent: HAP specialist discovered this package in the unload when placing several other damaged hazmats into lined totes for the HESS specialist to bring back to the damage area. As this was in the same MPS as the others and found in the same trailer, HAP specialist elected to have it inspected just in case. HESS specialist placed the package's tote atop the drain mats in the incoming damaged hazmat/LQ area. The following day, HESS specialist inspected the contents and found that one bottle had leaked. DescribePack: one bottle leaked due to loose cap DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: placed in lined tote, moved to drain mats. 4. X-2024010302 SequenceEvent: HAP specialist discovered this package in the unload when placing several other damaged hazmats into lined totes for the HESS specialist to bring back to the damage area. As this was in the same MPS as the others and found in the same trailer, HAP specialist elected to have it inspected just in case. HESS specialist placed the package's tote atop the drain mats in the incoming damaged hazmat/LQ area. The following day, HESS specialist inspected the contents and found that one bottle had leaked. DescribePack: one bottle leaked due to loose cap DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: placed in lined tote, moved to drain mats.

  • City: NORTH LITTLE ROCK
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Car found to be leaking from the bottom outlet cap at a rate of 2-3 gallons per minute. Upon arrival of the contractor, Code 3, the valve handle was in the closed, pinned, and sealed position and the bottom outlet cap was less than tool tight. Code 3 tightened the cap, stopping the release. After the car was set out, the contractor was able to climb under the car and determined that the valve was in the open position even with the handle closed. The handle was dropped to the open position, engaged, and the valve closed. The BOV plug was removed and verified the valve was closed with no release. The shipper was contacted and an OTMA was requested before the car would be released into transportation.

  • Description: The material shipped as 32/55-gallon drums (received on 10/17/23) of flammable liquids for recycling. The material was attempted to be recycled but did not result in an usable product. This resulted in the material not qualifying as a Hazardous Secondary Material. The material was managed as a hazardous waste with the waste codes of F005, F003, D001, and D035. Reclaimed Energy is permitted to accept these waste codes and managed the waste in an appropriate manner. The generator has been notified.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 10.4.23 at approximately 7:45am, during a transfer of Ferric Chloride from railcar(PVSX213032) into All-Chem trailer (FRP64) the air valve on the trailer malfunctioned causing a release. The loader immediately climbed down from the railcar and closed both the internal and external valves on the trailer. Approximately 2 gallons of product was released, notifications were made to proper NS, RSI, PVS and All-Chem personnel. Hepaco arrived on site around 12pm, cleaned up, removed all debris and departed around 2:15pm.
